metadata.title: One-pot three-component synthesis of 2-Amino-4H-Chromene derivatives by using monodisperse Pd nanomaterials anchored graphene oxide as highly efficient and recyclable catalyst

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano-Structures & Nano-Objects
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/nanoso
One-pot three-component synthesis of 2-Amino-4H-Chromene derivatives by using monodisperse Pd nanomaterials anchored graphene oxide as highly efficient and recyclable catalyst Suleyman Akocak a,*,1, Betül Şen b,1, Nabih Lolak a, Aysun Şavk b, Murat Koca a, Sultan Kuzu b, Fatih Şen b,* a Department of Pharmaceutical Chemistry, Faculty of Pharmacy, Adiyaman University, 02040 Adiyaman, Turkey b Sen Research Group, Biochemistry Department, Faculty of Arts and Science, Dumlupınar University, Evliya Çelebi Campus, 43100 Kutahya, Turkey
h i g h l i g h t s
• The discovery of a superior catalyst for the synthesis of 2-amino-4Hchromene derivatives. • Highlymonodisperse palladiumnanoparticles supported with graphene oxide (Pd@GO). • One of the highest catalytic activity of Pd@GO for the synthesis of 2- amino-4H-chromene derivatives. • Thanks to theultrasmall sizes,monodispersity and high Pd(0) % surface of the catalyst.
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 24 March 2017 Received in revised form 27 May 2017 Accepted 3 June 2017
Keywords: Chromene Highly efficient Monodispersity One pot reaction Pd nanocatalyst
a b s t r a c t
An efficient and environmentally benign method has been developed for the synthesis of 2-amino4H-chromene derivatives via one-pot multi component condensation of resorcinol (1), malononitrile (2), and various aromatic aldehydes (3a–j), using highly monodisperse palladium nanoparticles supported with graphene oxide (Pd@GO) as a heterogeneous catalyst. An advantageous of this method is that monodisperse Pd@GO nanoparticles can be easily separated and reused several times for further runs. This highly stable and monodisperse catalyst has been used for the first time as highly efficient, long lived and isolable catalyst for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives from resorcinol, aromatic aldehydes and malononitrile with great catalytic performance and easy work-up procedure. The structure and morphology of synthesized catalyst were characterized by using different techniques such as, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), the high resolution electron micrograph (HRTEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The highly crystalline, colloidally stable and highly monodisperse Pd@GO formation were shown by using these techniques. Besides, the Pd@GO has been found to be highly efficient and recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives.
© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
* Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: akocaksuleyman@gmail.com (S. Akocak),
fatihsen1980@gmail.com (F. Şen). 1 These authors equally contributed this work.
1. Introduction
In recent years, one potmulti component reactions (MCRs) have emerged as an attractive strategy within the fields of medicinal and organic synthetic chemistry as they require minimal workup, conducting the reaction without isolation of intermediates and
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoso.2017.06.002 2352-507X/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
simplicity. Especially, 2-amino-4H-choromenes and their derivatives have been synthesized using the MCR system with aromatic aldehydes, resorcinol and malononitrile [1–5]. Due to their antibacterial [6], antimicrobial [7,8], anti-inflammatory [9,10], antiproliferative [11], antioxidant [12], anti-HIV [13] and anticancer activities [14–16], the preparation of chromenes have attracted by researchers for pharmaceutical applications. In literature, various catalysts are used for the one-pot synthesis of 2-amino4H-chromene derivatives such as chitosan [17], K2CO3 [6,18], DBU [19], Na2CO3 under grinding [20], tungstic acid-SBA-153, potassium phthalimide-N-oxyl (POPINO) [21], Fe(HSO4)3 [22], aminoappended β-CDs (ACDs) [23], Fe3O4-chitosan nanoparticles [24], amino-silane modified Fe3O4 nanoparticles (MNPsNH2) [25], nano-sized MgO [26], KSF [27], [2-Eim]OAc [28], TPOP2 [2], N,N-dimethylaminoethylbenzyldimethylammonium chloride [29,30], Mg/Al-HT [1] etc. However, many of these reported methods show varying degrees of success as well as one or more limitations such as prolong reaction times, harsh reaction conditions, toxic reagents, low reusability, and low yields. Therefore, more efficient and reusable catalysts are still in demand for the synthesis of these kinds of reactions. Recently, carbon materials such as carbon nanotubes, carbon black, graphene oxide (GO), reduced graphene oxides (rGO) etc. are interested by researchers due to their surface functional groups, high specific surface area, structural defect, excellent electrical conductivity and high mechanical strength [31–41]. Specifically, the chemically active sites of GO is mostly used in catalytic reactions and also act as the anchoring sites for chemical functionalization, metal particles immobilization, and inorganic complexes, etc. All these reasons make the GO evenmore attractive in various applications such as sensors, semiconductor devices, nanoelectronics, photo-catalysis, super capacitors, and as catalysts formany organic reactions [31–41]. In continuation of our recent efforts to develop efficient one-potmulti component reactions using heterogeneous catalysts [31–34],we herein report the synthesis of Graphene oxide-Palladiumnanocomposites (Pd@GO), and demonstrate its application as reusable, isolable, long-lived, and efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives. These derivatives were also characterized by melting points, FT-IR,1H-NMR and13C-NMR analyses. The current Pd@GO nanocomposites have been used for the first time as a catalyst for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives.
2. Experimental
2.1. Synthesis of Pd@GO
Pd@GO has been prepared by a sonochemical double solvent reduction method. As a summary of this method, superhydride and ethanol were used to reduce the mixture of 0.25 mmol (0.081 g) of Pd dissolved in small amount of anhydrous tetrahydrofuran and 0.25 mmol of 1-aminooctane ligands for 1 h in an ultrasonic condition. The brown–black color of the solution indicated that the Pd nanoparticles was obtained. The prepared Pd were mixed in a 1:1 ratio with GO by using tip sonicator. Finally, the solid Pd@GO nanoparticles were dried under vacuum at room temperature.

sections.heading: 2.2. General procedure for preparation of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives (4a–j) using Pd@GO as the catalyst
sections.text:
A mixture of 1 mmol resorcinol (1), 1 mmol malononitrile (2), 1 mmol aldehyde derivatives (3a–j), and Pd@GO (10 mg) in 10 mL ethanol were refluxed in an oil bath for an appropriate time (10–15 min). The reaction progress was monitored by TLC. The reaction mixture was then cooled to room temperature and the catalyst was recovered. The solid product was filtered, washed with 500mLwater, and recrystallized fromethanol (88%–94%). The yield, melting points and characterization of all compounds were summarized in Supplementary part.
3. Results and discussion
The sonochemical double solvent reduction method was applied to produce monodisperse Pd@GO catalyst at room temperature. At the beginning of the reaction, Pd(0) nanoparticles quickly accumulate and precipitate out of the THF solution without stabilizing and supporting material such as 1-aminooctane and GO, respectively. The Pd@GO had strong resistance to agglomeration overmonths when the 1-aminooctane and GOwere used together. This result indicates that the 1-aminooctane ligand and GO are very strong and efficient stabilizing agents for the Pd@GO catalyst preparation. The solid nanoparticles can be isolated by evaporating the solvent under vacuum after washing the Pd@GO with dry ethanol to eliminate excess ligand. The preliminary characterizations of Pd@GO were performed by using TEM, XPS, HRTEM, XRD and Raman spectroscopy methods.
The XRD spectra of Pd@GO are given in Fig. 1(a). The XRD measurements show that Pd@GO have diffraction peaks of faceentered cubic (fcc) crystal lattice at around 2θ = 40.22, 46.74, 68.37, 82.21 that are due to Pd (111), (200), (220) and (311), respectively (JCPDS card numbers 87-0637 of Pd). Besides, the peak at around 11.9◦ is attributed to the GO. The average crystallite sizes of themetal particles and lattice parameters (αPd) were calculated with Pd (220) diffraction peaks of the prepared catalyst. The lattice constant values was found to be 3.891 Å, which is in good agreementwith 3.890Å for pure Pd [35–37].Moreover, the average crystallite palladium particle size of Pd@GO were calculated to be about 3.90 ± 0.41 nm, using the Scherrer equation [38].
Another effective way to distinguish the ordered and disordered structure of carbon in carbonaceous materials is Raman spectroscopy. In Fig. 1(b), Raman spectrum of GO and Pd@GO are shown in detail. Two remarkable scattering peaks located at 1351 and 1582 cm−1 can be assigned to the E2g phonon of sp2 carbon atoms (D-band) and breathing mode of κ-point phonons of A1g symmetry (G-band), respectively. The intensity ratio of D to G band (ID/IG) could be used to evaluate the degree of modification or defects of GO. In this work, the ID/IG values of GO and Pd@GOwere found to be 1.05 and 1.15, respectively which indicates that the increasing disorder in the GO lattice after functionalization with Pd.
In order to study the chemical state variations of the Pd@GO, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to designate the surface composition and the oxidation state of Pd. For this aim, the Pd 3d region of spectrum was analyzed and fitted by usingGaussian–Lorentzianmethod and the relative intensity of the species was calculated by the help of the integration of each peak. Accurate binding energies (±0.3 eV) were decided by referencing to the C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV at XPS spectrum. For the prepared catalyst, doublet consists of two double Pd 3d photoelectron spectrum is shown in Fig. 1(c), (d). The line at 334.8–340.9 eV is undoubtedly due to Pd(0), while the Pd (II) peaks at 338.3–343.1 eV in Fig. 1(c) may be caused by the surface oxidation and/or chemisorption of environmental oxygen during the preparation process [31–41]. This result indicates that Pd is mostly in zero oxidation state (% 80.6) in the prepared catalyst. Besides, as shown in Figure S3a, the C1s XPS spectrum of the pristine GO exhibits four different peaks centered at 284.0, 284.8, 287.4 and 290.6 eV, corresponding to sp3 C, C = O, C–O and O = C–O groups, respectively.
Micro-structural features and morphology of the Pd@GO were analyzed by TEM, HRTEM and particle size histogram showing the highly monodisperse morphology of the catalyst as indicated in Fig. 2(a)–(d). The TEM results also showed that most of the particles were spherical and no agglomerations were observed in the prepared catalyst as shown in Fig. 2(a). Besides, Fig. 2(a) also indicates the atomic lattice fringes obtained by HRTEM for Pd@GO and it is found that Pd (111) plane spacing is 0.22 nm that is
exactly same with nominal Pd value in the literature [36,39,40]. The average particle size of Pd@GO is found as 3.54 ± 0.93 nm and a uniform distribution of the catalyst particles with a very narrow range on graphene oxide was detected in Fig. 2(b). EELS mapping and line profile of Pd@GO also indicates the existence of Pd in prepared catalyst as shown in Fig. 2(c) and (d).
After the characterization of Pd@GO was performed, an efficient and environmentally benign method has been developed for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives via an one-pot multi component condensation of resorcinol (1), malononitrile (2), and various aromatic aldehydes (3a–j), using highly monodisperse palladium nanoparticles supported with graphene oxide (Pd@GO) as a recyclable heterogeneous catalyst. For this purpose, to determine the best reaction conditions, various parameters such as, temperature, solvents, reaction time and amount of catalyst were studied. Resorcinol, benzaldehyde, andmalonitrile were chosen as model reactants under different conditions (Table 1). The effect of different solvents such as, water, ethanol, isopropanol, dichloromethane, dimethylformamide, and acetonitrile has been evaluated on the reaction rate under the same reaction conditions. From the model reaction, ethanol was chosen as an optimum solventwith the shortest reaction time andhighest yield among them. Then, the reaction temperature was adjusted with the best solvent (ethanol) at 80 ◦C. In order to evaluate the optimum amount of catalyst required for the synthesize of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives, the reaction was carried out in the presence of varying amount of catalyst (5, 10 and 20 mg) in ethanol at 80 ◦C. From Table 1, it can be concluded that 10 mg of Pd@GO is the amount of catalyst needed to conduct this condensation reactionwith ethanol as a solvent at 80 ◦C.
The optimized reaction condition was further extended to different aromatic aldehydes with malononitrile and resorcinol to synthesize corresponding 2-amino-4H-choromene derivatives. The reaction procedure and obtained products were summarized in Scheme 1. The colors of synthesized compounds were as white to dark yellow and characterized bymelting points, FT-IR, 1H-NMR and13C-NMR (See supplementary data for detail). A comparison of the catalytic activities of the different heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literature with that of prepared Pd@GO to synthesize the compound of the model reaction (4a) is indicated in Table 2. The current Pd@GO catalyst method offers several advantageous over most of the literature methods such as, a short reaction time, simple work-up procedure, high reusability of catalyst, high yields etc. [2,3,21–23,25,26,28].
The probable reactionmechanism for the synthesis of 2-amino4H-chromene derivatives in the presence of Pd@GO is shown in Scheme 2. Firstly, GO binds with the oxygen of the carbonyl groupmakes the alpha hydrogen very acidic, thereby involving the Knoevenagel condensation reaction between aromatic aldehyde and malononitrile. In the second step, Knoevenagel product was reacted in a Michael addition with resorcinol to produce desired product after rearomatization and intramolecular cyclization with the help of Pd@GO as a catalyst.
The reusability and recoverability of the heterogeneous catalyst was tested as shown in Fig. 3 using the model reaction under
the optimized reaction conditions. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was easily removed from the reaction medium by using centrifugation. Then, it was washed several times with methanol, water and dried under vacuum and reused again. From Fig. 3, Pd@GO catalyst can be reused more than six times without any significant decrease about catalytic function. It looks like highly stable and reusable catalyst. We have thought the reason
why the catalytic performance was decreased and checked the TEM images and ICP results for the catalyst before and after the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives. It was found that we could not see any leaching during the reaction but some agglomerations (particle size increase) were seen after the 6th usage of catalyst. The decrease in % conversion after 6th usage of catalyst can be explained by increasing of particle size of Pd@GO NPs.
4. Conclusions
In summary, monodisperse Pd@GO has been successfully synthesized and fully characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), the high resolution electronmicrograph (HRTEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives with the various aromatic aldehydes, resorcinol and malononitrile in the presence of highly stable, isolable, exceptional reusable, bottleable, long-lived and highly efficient monodisperse graphene oxide furnished Pd nanoparticles has been developed as an effective and practical synthetic method. This highly monodisperse and heterogeneous catalyst is one of the most efficient catalysts which gives the highest yields of desired products in the shortest time with excellent yields. This is most likely due to highly monodispersed, high chemical surface area, low crystallite particle size and high Pd(0) % contents of graphene oxide furnished Pd nanoparticles. Further, the given methodology is effective and environmentally benign and offers several advantages such as, simple work-up and high yields possible due to no air or moisture sensitivity of the catalyst.
Acknowledgments
This research was financed by Dumlupinar University Research Fund (Grant No. 2014-05 and 2015-35). The partial supports by Science Academy and Fevzi Akkaya Research Funding (FABED) are gratefully acknowledged.

In literature, various catalysts are used for the one-pot synthesis of 2-amino4H-chromene derivatives such as chitosan [17], K2CO3 [6,18], DBU [19], Na2CO3 under grinding [20], tungstic acid-SBA-153, potassium phthalimide-N-oxyl (POPINO) [21], Fe(HSO4)3 [22], aminoappended β-CDs (ACDs) [23], Fe3O4-chitosan nanoparticles [24], amino-silane modified Fe3O4 nanoparticles (MNPsNH2) [25], nano-sized MgO [26], KSF [27], [2-Eim]OAc [28], TPOP2 [2], N,N-dimethylaminoethylbenzyldimethylammonium chloride [29,30], Mg/Al-HT [1] etc.
